se.code77.jq

Interface Promise<V>

  • Type Parameters:
    V - Type of the value carried by the promise
    All Superinterfaces:
    java.util.concurrent.Future<V>

    public interface Promise<V>
extends java.util.concurrent.Future<V>
    A Promises/A+ style promise offering simple, chainable asynchronous invocations.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Interface and Description
      static interface  Promise.OnFulfilledCallback<V,NV>
      Callback interface for resolved/fulfilled promises.
      static interface  Promise.OnRejectedCallback<NV>
      Callback interface for rejected promises.
      static class  Promise.State
      State of a promise.
      static class  Promise.StateSnapshot<V>
      The state snapshot of a promise as returned by inspect().
      static class  Promise.UnhandledRejectionException
      An exception thrown by a promise which is terminated without any rejection callback.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      boolean cancel(boolean mayInterruptIfRunning)
      Canceling promises is not supported since a promise is completely decoupled from the task and only observable (its state may be changed only through the Deferred object).
      Promise<V> delay(long ms)
      Delays a resolved promise by the specified time, by creating a new promise that will inherit the state of this promise; if this promise is rejected, the new promise will also be immediately rejected but if this promise is resolved, the new promise will be resolved when the specified time has passed.
      void done()
      Adds a default rejection handler and then terminates the promise chain.
      void done(Promise.OnFulfilledCallback<V,java.lang.Void> onFulfilled)
      Adds the supplied fulfillment handler, just like calling then(OnFulfilledCallback), but also adds a default rejection handler and then terminates the promise chain.

      Adds the supplied callback handlers, just like calling then(OnFulfilledCallback, OnRejectedCallback), but also adds a default rejection handler and then terminates the promise chain.

      Observe the state of this promise by adding callbacks which will be called when the promise is resolved or rejected.
      Promise<V> timeout(long ms)
      Add a timeout to a promise by returning a new promise that will be rejected with a TimeoutException when the specified time has passed if this promise isn't completed by then.

      • then

        <NV> Promise<NV> then(Promise.OnFulfilledCallback<V,NV> onFulfilled,
                      Promise.OnRejectedCallback<NV> onRejected)
        Observe the state of this promise by adding callbacks which will be called when the promise is resolved or rejected. This method will return a new promise which will be chained to this promise, so that any value returned from or exception thrown by any of the invoked callbacks will be carried over to the new promise. This means that callbacks may be chained such as p.then(...).then(...).then(...).fail(...) etc. The supplied callbacks will be invoked on the thread from which this method is called. If the promise is already completed when this method is called, the relevant callback (onFulfilled or onRejected) will be dispatched for immediate execution in a future event loop turn, but will never be inlined. Note that this method MUST be run on a thread implementing an event loop.
        Type Parameters:
        NV - Type of the value returned by the callback handlers
        Parameters:
        onFulfilled - Fulfillment handler
        onRejected - Rejection handler
        Returns:
        A new promise that will be resolved with the value returned/rejected with the reason thrown from any of the callback handlers.

      • then

        <NV> Promise<NV> then(Promise.OnFulfilledCallback<V,NV> onFulfilled)
        Observe the state of this promise by adding a fulfillment callback which will be called when the promise is resolved. This is the same as calling then(OnFulfilledCallback, OnRejectedCallback) with null as the onRejected argument. Note that this method MUST be run on a thread implementing an event loop.
        Type Parameters:
        NV - Type of the value returned by the callback handlers
        Parameters:
        onFulfilled - Fulfillment handler
        Returns:
        A new promise that will be resolved with the value returned/rejected with the reason thrown from the supplied callback handler.
        See Also:
        then(OnFulfilledCallback, OnRejectedCallback)

      • fail

        <NV> Promise<NV> fail(Promise.OnRejectedCallback<NV> onRejected)
        Observe the state of this promise by adding a rejection callback which will be called when the promise is rejected. This is the same as calling then(OnFulfilledCallback, OnRejectedCallback) with null as the onFulfilled argument. Note that this method MUST be run on a thread implementing an event loop.
        Type Parameters:
        NV - Type of the value returned by the callback handlers
        Parameters:
        onRejected - Rejection handler
        Returns:
        A new promise that will be resolved with the value returned/rejected with the reason thrown from the supplied callback handler.
        See Also:
        then(OnFulfilledCallback, OnRejectedCallback)

      • done

        void done(Promise.OnFulfilledCallback<V,java.lang.Void> onFulfilled,
          Promise.OnRejectedCallback<java.lang.Void> onRejected)
        Adds the supplied callback handlers, just like calling then(OnFulfilledCallback, OnRejectedCallback), but also adds a default rejection handler and then terminates the promise chain. It's good practice to terminate a promise chain to avoid unhandled rejections to silently pass unnoticed. If an unterminated chain of promises without a rejection handler is rejected, nothing will happen. However, a terminated chain will result in a UnhandledRejectionException carrying the rejection reason to be thrown on the dispatcher thread. Since this exception will typically not be possible to catch, this means the application is likely to crash. Clients should take caution to always include a rejection handler, and should consider termination of promise chains as an aid during development. Note that this method MUST be run on a thread implementing an event loop.
        Parameters:
        onFulfilled - Fulfillment handler
        onRejected - Rejection handler

      • done

        void done(Promise.OnFulfilledCallback<V,java.lang.Void> onFulfilled)
        Adds the supplied fulfillment handler, just like calling then(OnFulfilledCallback), but also adds a default rejection handler and then terminates the promise chain. It's good practice to terminate a promise chain to avoid unhandled rejections to silently pass unnoticed. If an unterminated chain of promises without a rejection handler is rejected, nothing will happen. However, a terminated chain will result in a UnhandledRejectionException carrying the rejection reason to be thrown on the dispatcher thread. Since this exception will typically not be possible to catch, this means the application is likely to crash. Clients should take caution to always include a rejection handler, and should consider termination of promise chains as an aid during development. Note that this method MUST be run on a thread implementing an event loop.
        Parameters:
        onFulfilled - Fulfillment handler

      • done

        void done()
        Adds a default rejection handler and then terminates the promise chain. It's good practice to terminate a promise chain to avoid unhandled rejections to silently pass unnoticed. If an unterminated chain of promises without a rejection handler is rejected, nothing will happen. However, a terminated chain will result in a UnhandledRejectionException carrying the rejection reason to be thrown on the dispatcher thread. Since this exception will typically not be possible to catch, this means the application is likely to crash. Clients should take caution to always include a rejection handler, and should consider termination of promise chains as an aid during development. Note that this method MUST be run on a thread implementing an event loop.

      • timeout

        Promise<V> timeout(long ms)
        Add a timeout to a promise by returning a new promise that will be rejected with a TimeoutException when the specified time has passed if this promise isn't completed by then. Note that this method MUST be run on a thread implementing an event loop.
        Parameters:
        ms - Timeout, in milliseconds
        Returns:
        New promise

      • delay

        Promise<V> delay(long ms)
        Delays a resolved promise by the specified time, by creating a new promise that will inherit the state of this promise; if this promise is rejected, the new promise will also be immediately rejected but if this promise is resolved, the new promise will be resolved when the specified time has passed. Note that this method MUST be run on a thread implementing an event loop.
        Parameters:
        ms - Time to delay resolved promise, in milliseconds
        Returns:
        New promise

      • join

        Promise<V> join(Promise<V> that)
        Creates a new promise that will wait for the two promises to complete, and which will be resolved if and only if the two promises are resolved with the exact same value. If any of the promises are rejected, the new promise will be immediately rejected as well. If both promises are resolved but with different values, the new promise will be rejected. Note that this method MUST be run on a thread implementing an event loop.
        Parameters:
        that - A promise
        Returns:
        A promise that will be resolved only if both promises are resolved with the same value; rejected otherwise

      • get

        V get()
throws java.lang.InterruptedException,
      java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException
        Returns the resolved value carried by this promise. If the value is not readily available, this method will block while waiting for the promise to be completed or an interrupt to occur. Calling this method on a dispatcher thread might cause a deadlock. If the promise is rejected, an ExecutionException will be thrown, wrapping the rejection reason.
        Specified by:
        get in interface java.util.concurrent.Future<V>
        Returns:
        The value carried by this promise
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException - If the blocked thread was interrupted
        java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException - If the promise was rejected, the reason will be wrapped in an ExecutionException.

      • get

        V get(long timeout,
      java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit unit)
throws java.lang.InterruptedException,
      java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException,
      java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException
        Returns the resolved value carried by this promise. If the value is not readily available, this method will block while waiting for the promise to be completed or an interrupt to occur, however for no longer than the supplied duration. Calling this method on a dispatcher thread might cause a deadlock. If the promise is rejected, an ExecutionException will be thrown, wrapping the rejection reason.
        Specified by:
        get in interface java.util.concurrent.Future<V>
        Returns:
        The value carried by this promise
        Throws:
        java.lang.InterruptedException - If the blocked thread was interrupted
        java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException - If the promise was rejected, the reason will be wrapped in an ExecutionException.
        java.util.concurrent.TimeoutException - If the promise was not completed before the specified duration passed.

      • cancel

        boolean cancel(boolean mayInterruptIfRunning)
        Canceling promises is not supported since a promise is completely decoupled from the task and only observable (its state may be changed only through the Deferred object). This method will always return false.
        Specified by:
        cancel in interface java.util.concurrent.Future<V>
